div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: THE FALL IN CONSOLS.
div.p:
1 Mr. Asquith meant well when, on July 10, at the opening of the new buildings of the United Kingdom Temperance Institution, he expressed the opinion that the fall in high class investment securities was at its worst, that we had "touched bottom," and that "the upward "process had begun." He would have done, well to remember the words of the sage who said that prophecy is of all errors the most gratuitous. People are grateful to those who foretell smooth things, at the moment they are uttered; but when subsequent events belie the soothsayer they are apt to stone him. Mr. Asquith runs no risk of stoning, says the "Times" but many a bitter gibe has been bestowed upon him of late in the City for having "given himself "away" so completely. It is only fair to say, however, that a good many of those who are now jeering were much of his opinion a month ago, and that at that time

there appeared to be fair grounds for the views he expressed. Nevertheless it was not a judicious atteranceon the part of a Chancellor. of the Exchequer. On July 9, the day before Mr. Asquith made his encouraging reference to the probable future of the market for "good securities," Consols stood at 844 for cash ; a day or two after the speech there was a slight rally, but it did not last, and by the end of the month the price was 82 15/16. Since then the decline has been continuous, and yesterdåy the price touched 813/16, closing at814. This is a fall of 27 since July 9. The heavy drop since the August Bank Holiday, amounting to 1 3/16, has struck some critics as surprising, in view of the magnificent character of the foreign trade returns for July published yesterday, the increase in the exports being over £7,000,000. It is thought, apparently, that the depression of the British Funds simultaneously with the expansion of British trade abroad forms a paradox. As a matter of fact, active trade and high prices for securities with a low yield are incompatible ; for active trade means high rates for money ; business men do not want to buy or hold Three per Cent, investments at a time when they can make a great deal more in their own businesses There are other reasons, as readers of our City Article are aware, for the weakness of what are known as "gilt-nedged" stocks. To begin with, the number and volume of these stocks have been very greatly increased during the last seven years, and what is even more effective as a cause of their depreciation--there have been enormous creations of other stocks and bonds of fair quality, yielding rates of interest much in excess of the highest grade securities, which have proved attractive to investors, especially to the modern type of investor, who shows a rather dangerous disposition to combine investment with a little speculation-a result, we fear, of the increased extravagance of living which has been a feature of the last ten years."

It must also be remembered that certain "untoward events" have happened during the last year which were of a nature to bring Consols and other high-class stocks to market. We refer more particularly to the earthquake at San Francisco last year. There can be no doubt that this disaster led to some sales by insurance companies of this class of security, and also, which was much more serious for the market, to a cessation of purchases. The insurance companies did not resume baying until April this year, and, even then, they did not show much liking for Consols ; there was other metal more attractive. Altogether careful students of the phenomenon under consideration are very much of the same mind as Sir Charles Scotter, whose remarks on the depreciation of railway and other securities; addressed to the meeting of the London and South-Western Railway Company, were reported in "The Times" yesterday. There is yet another cause for the extent to which Consols and other stocks yielding until recently 3 per cent. or less, have fallen out of favour-namely, the fact that many investors have been induced to act on what is known as the "geographical system" of investment, under which securities of States, cities, and companies in various portions of the world are purchased with the object of "spreading" risks. The advantages, such as they are, of this method of investment have been pointed out in "The Times," with their limitations, which some of the advocates of this plan have neg. lected to note. These limitations are pretty obvious, however. It must surely be obvious, for instance, that investments in railways abroad are subject to all the risks, including strikes, to which such undertakings are liable here; and that other classes of foreign investments are under similar disabilities. The chief reason for buying them was that their yields made them worth the risk, if taken in small quantities. It is easy to understand that when Consols yielded under 3 per cent. British municipal and colonial stocks little. over 3 per apcent., and the best British railway stocks aboat 1 37 per cent, it was worth while to look abroad in order to raise the average yield of a sum to be invested ; and it was frequently done. The recent decline in British securities suggests, however, that a time may come before very long when these temporarily despised investments may once more attract attention, by reason of their improved yields, especially | as some of the foreign securities so freely recommended by the admirers of the "geo . i I graphical plan" have not fully answered expectations in the matter of maintaining their prices.

div.head: Cairo Museum
div.p: The above museum has just received å magnificent sarcophagus in granite, 'one metre and a half high, representing King Amenothes II. This valuable addition was lately found in the excavations at Karnak.

div.head: Quarantine.
div.p: The Quarantine Board, having forwarded a report to the Ministry of the Interior on the unsatisfactory condition. of the quarantine Station at Gabbary, the latter has replied to the effect that the board will be granted an area of land at Mex, but must hand over the Gabbary Station to the Government.

div.head: A Serious Acoident.
div.p: A porter, named Ali Mahmoud, while placing a box in the luggage compartment of a train standing in the Cairo railway station on Sunday, lost his footing and fell between the trucks, injuring himself so severely that his life is despaired of at the hospital, where he was immediately taken.

div.head: Projected Press Syndioate.
div.p: At a meeting of European journalists, on Sunday evening, at the Continental Hotel Cairo, it was decided, on the suggestion of Mr. Colrat of the "Egyptian Morning News," to form a syndicate of journalists and a committee was then elected in order to draw up the statutes of the proposed syndicate

div.head: A Daring Robbery.
div.p: An exceptionally during robbery took place on Friday last at Nawa police station, in the Kaliou bieh district. While the shawishes on duty were taking a short post-prandial nap, ' the station was entered and robbed of 10 rifles, belonging to the Egyptian Army.Every endeavour to trace thrę identity of the thieves or their whereabouts has been unavailing and, in the meanwhile, four shawishes have been placed under arrest.

div.head: Bubonic Plague. .
div.p: During the week ending the 19th Instant, 10 cases of plagne were registered throughout Egypt, of which 7 were reported from Alexandria, 2 from Port Said and one occurred in the district of Damanhour. From the beginning of the year to the 19th August, 1063 cases of bubonic plague have been dealt with, its against 425, registered during the .corresponding period of last year. One recovery at Alexandria was the only case reported during the past 24 hours. Eight patients' are still under treatment. New

div.head: Calro School.
div.p: Mgr. Cyrille VIII, Greek-Catholic patriarch of Europe is starting a new school at Cairo which is arranged on interesting lines. It will commerke on 1st September, and will follow the programme of the Egyptian Government chools. Ut will be established at Fagallah and will accept scholars of all creeds and nationalities. The instruction in English, French and Arabic is to be given by lay-masters, under clerical supervision. Mgr. Maecarius Saba has been charged with the induction of the school and the engagement of professors. Omnibuses will be at the service of the pupils and every effort will be made to give a broad and extensive education.

div.head: Praotioal Jokers Rewarded. -
div.p: With the innocent intention of playing a practical joke on a friend, two cigarette rollers of Greek nationality, name: Nicolas Kastaras and Stavros Mossinghides, 'accompanied by two women, proceeded in a carriage, at about 2 o'clock a.m. on Sunday morning, to a house in Sharia Maarouf, where they began to sing beneath the window of a mutual friend, named Nicolas Floros; but the latter, who had just returned from a long day's shooting, failed to appreciate the humour of the situation and seizing his loaded gun, which stood by the window, he promptly fired upon his friends below, wounding the driver, named "Pokas, also of Greek nationality. Floros was immediately taken into custody and has been handed | . * over to his. Consul to be dealt with..

div.head: Wrestling in Cairo
div.p: According to reports appearing in most of the Cairo papers, nearly every nation of the world has sent out their champion wrestler to take part in a battle royal, which is billed to commence at the "Théâtre des Ambassadeurs" on Wednesday evening next; and it would also appear that the champion of the world" will himself assist thereat. Although the claim of the forthcoming combatants to the title of champion of this or that may be scarcely generally admitted, and despite the improbability of such illustrious professionals as the World's or England's champion coming to Cairo at this season, still there is no doubt that a really excellent exhibition ought to be witnessed on Wednesday. This evening a benefit perfor. Tance, on behalf of Mme Saxe, will be given at the Théâtre des Nouveautés, and an excellent programme, containing boxing and wrestling matches, besides the usual music hall tårns, has been drawn up for the oecasion,

div.head:
AMERICAN GOLD FOR EGYPT.
NESESSARY TO MOVE THE COTTON CROP
div.p: Mr. Cope Whitehouse writes as follows to the "Manchester Guardian" from New York under date of the 26th vlt. :

Sir, -The "New York Times" publishes today a cable summary of a leading article in the "Manchester Guardian" under the title "Fear of Japan's Credit." It places at about £200,000,000 sterling the amount borrowed by Japan in England for war and other less de structive purposes, and expresses the opinion that the English public feels that it has loaned as much as the circumstances appear to justify: The amount lent to Japan is about the same as that of the European commitments in Egypt. The month of August is the critical period in that country for three results of its dependence on the annual rise of the Nile. Assuming that the river has already risen sufficiently to give the water needed for irrigation-- about 50,000,000 cubic mètres daily, it remains to be seen whether it will rise high enough to provide for the inundation of flood crops of cereals, or perhaps so much too high as to breach a bank, with the consequent destruction of life and property. This has happened repeatedly in recent times, especially since the canalisation of the Delta. The increase of the embankments in Middle Egypt has added to the danger. There is also the climatic conditions of this month, in which, owing to fog, there may be a serious loss in a crop that had previonsly promised the best results. The danger of à food and the magnitude of past disasters are lucidly described by Sir W. Garstin in Appendix I. of the Parliamentary Report, August, 1904, on the Basin of the Upper Nile. It yas widely believed that the Assouan Dam had been sanctioned because it would control the Nile in flood. | Bnt, aś iş now generally known, this "open dam," with a sectional area of less than 22,000 square feet in its sluiceways, heads up the river during flood, and only suffices to discharge even less than the maximum of 1,000,000,000 cubic metres daily by the high velocity given to the natural current. It was the opinion of M. Boulé, the French member of the Technical Commission, that the only feasible plan would have been that of large openings closed by "barrages submersibles.

While opposed myself to any sort of construction at any point across the bed of the Nile, there would have been no danger from the Dam at Assonan had the patnral channels of the river been cleared away ! and discharge channels provided, similarly prepared and protected against scour, to carry off the water at right. angles to the face of the structure or in the axis of the respective currents. At all events, the planger of a breach in an earth bank, whether in the Delta .or in Middle Egypt, has not been diminished. Should á disaster occur, it would be necessary for Egypt to borrow a considerable sum to meet the emergency, and its financial condition would then be one of the utmost importance. The Guaranteed Debt is below par, although the six Powers are jointly and severally liable for interest an principal. The individual credit of the endorsers is also below 3 per cent with Consols at their present price. There is no tabulated statement of the liabilities of the Egyptian Government in the Parliamentary Report tor 1906. The guaranteed loans, such as £500,000 of the municipality of | Alexandria or of the issues of the Agricultural Bank, should have been mentioned. The credit of Alexandria would appear to most financiers to'be better than that of the State; while the Agricultural Bank ought not to sustain any loss except as the result of some disaster which had destroyed the minor canals and the productive capacity of a considerable area. But in that event the desolation of the country would be so widespread as to compel immeiate suspension of all Government payments from internal resources for external obligations. The Turkish tribute equals £20,000,000

to be added to the £95,000,000 outstanding. · The irrigation certificates issued by the AssJouan Syndicate have been "assumed" by the Government. Lord Cromer stated that the Government had parted with its special gold reserye in January, 1905, and taken in its place a block of its own stock, which would be put upon the market at such time as might appear expedient. There are various credits tor expenditures in the Sudan and elsewhere, and an extraordinary expenditure for the repairs of the bed of the Nile where it has been scoured by the water passing through the dam. There is also the cost of the new dam, which is now under contract, intended to strengthen the existing structure, and possibly to supply, in 1902, an additional amount of water. A project for the sewering of Cairo has been elaborated. It is evident that no loan for these works could be negotiated in London at 4 per cent except on the general endorsement by the | Government. It does not seem too much to ask, therefore, that a brief financial statement of all the liabilities should be obtained by a question in the House of Commons, even if the results prove to be less optimistic than would be expected by those who derive their informatiori from the general assurances of prosperity which have been put forward with confidence.

For example, at the launching of the" "Cairo". Boghoz Pasha is reported to have said that the output of cotton as well as cereals had doubled. As no period was mentioned, be might have said, a thousand fold since the cotton crop of 1827, but if he referred to the last decade or to the quinquennial perioal since the completion of the Assouan Dam and its inauguration by the Duke of Connaught, the statistics show that there has been no permanent annual in. erease, as Manchester manufacturers and capitalists are well aware 5 while Lord Oromer says that the direct gain to the Treasury from the reservoir has been insignificant. In other words, it has not been sufficient to meet the instalments of the irrigation certificates.

The cereal export twenty years ago was more than enough to feed a million inhabitants of Europe and the sugar, by reason of its almost ideal perfection, was held in a high esteem as "the best Joannovich" in the cotton world. It is now inconsiderable. Food supplies are imported to replace the beans, barley, lentils, and wheat formerly grown on the fandated lands of Middle Egypt and the rice of the Northern belt

The prosperity of a country is dependent upon many factors, and the problem becomes more difficult when the question at issue is its relation to that of other lands which may profit by its adversities. Now the financial condition of Egypt has become a question of great interest to the financial authorities in New York. They are inquiring whether it may not be necessary to send gold from the Sub Treasury in the near future to help Europe to move the cotton crop. They have made the disquieting, if not alarming, discovery that if all the gold from the Transvaal were diverted at Suez from the first of September to the first of March it would not insure the regular weekly delivery of 2,000 bales in Boston, or 10,000 in Manchester and Liverpool and 8,000 bales to the Continent. The planters want minted gold, not bars. Their predecessors between 1860 and 1876 sold their cotton for £106,000,000 sterling. Probably £40,000,000 in gold came from the United States. There were hundreds of tons in silver and more than fifty tons of gold shipped out of the country after the arrival or M. de Blignières, Mr. Goschen (now Lord Goschen, and Mr. Rivers Wilson (now Sir Rivers Wilson). It is doubtful whether in | 1886 there was as much as £5,000,000 in what might be called tangible hoards--in other words, in a forin in which it could have been extracted by any of the methods practised with marked success between 1876 and 1896 and returned to Europe. Not only had the gold been exported, but even the silver ornaments of the women. But the conditions have changed by the creation of a class too numerons to be I treated individually, as was Ismail Sadyk, whose squeeze yielded, it is said, £15,000,000; or the Princes and Princesses now suing for a balance of £5,000,000 ; or that of the Khedive Ismail himself.

The rachat militaire, or purchased exemption from military service, is easily met; and what is an increase of £0.10.0 per acre in a land tax to a planter whose cotton is selling at about 10d. per pound; The present stock of gold in private hands in Egypt is thought to be over £35,000,000, but it is hoarded, and we believe that it is not available, for the present at all events, in view of the recent failure of banks in Alexahdria, The Finance Bills which were used to move the crops from 1902 to 1905 are discredited. The paper money offered by a buyer cannot compete on reasonable terms with a pile of gold in the hands of a rival. Why should the planter be in any hurry to sell his cotton if he has--as in one recent case cited by. Lord Cromer-£80,000 (£8,000 ?] in sovereigns in his private reserve? Offered 8 per cent for the use of his cotton or its equivalent until it dan be marketed here or in Europe, he rejects the proposal as contrary to the teachings of the Koran; and praises Allah because he made 23 per cent by the natural rise, while his less serupulous neighbour lost control of the proceeds of his crop through the suspension of the Cassa di Sconto e di Risparmio.

Putting the question with the frankness | which the occasion demands--Can Europe move a crop worth £30,000,000 without getting £5,000,000 in twenty-dollar gold pieces out of the sub-treasury in New York before August 15th ; and will you not probably require a delivery of £10,000,000 before the Ist of November, with no prospect of its return until there has been a complete reorganisation of the banking system in Alexandria and Cairo, or some method devised to induce or compel the 400,000 planters who will receive it to restore it to circulation

div.head: THE COTTON WORM
div.p: The destruction of the above pest continued during the week 'ending 15th August with the following results :
'The provinces of Assiout, Beni-Sonef, Fayoum, Ghizeh and Keneh were immune
In Behera 5394 feddans in 139 villages were infected and cleared.
In Dakablieh 207 feddans in 65 villages were infected and cleared,
In Gharbieh 1263 feddans in 82 villages were infected and cleared.
In Kalioubieh 1259 feddans in 131 villages were infected and cleared. · In Menoufieh 1 feddan in 20 villages were infected and cleared.
In Sharkieh 470 feddans in 15 villages were infected and cleared.
Thronghont the country, we are glad to report that 8,594 feddans in 452 villages were infected and cleared.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Earl of Cromer has arrived at Castle Leod, Ross-shire, on a visit to Mr. Thomas Baring, the shooting tenant.
Prince Aziz Pasba Hassan has arrived at Constantinople, where he will await the arrival of the Khedive and accompany his Highness on his return to Egypt..
The Sultan has conferred the rank of Lewa (Pasba) on Ibrahim Bey Halim.
Among those who arrived this morning by the M. M. "Congo" were Hassan Hassem Pasha, Mr. Barber, Mr. Toy, Mr. Mercier, Mr. Patterson, Mr. Mason, Mr. Graham, Mr. Frank, and Mr. R. P. Forest.

To-day will be celebrated in Switzerland the wedding of Miss Rosy Allemann, eldest daughter of Mr. C. L. Alemann, one of the partners of J. Planta & Co., to Dr. Julius Weber, attached to the large Aluminium Works of Nenhausen (Switzerland).
Brevet Lieut.-Colonel John Edmond Gongh, V .C., has been appointed to the vacancy among

the King's Aides-de-Camp, in succession to Colonel Sir H. G. Dixon, K.C.B. Lient.. Colonel Gough is a son of General Sir Charles John Stanley Gough, V.C., who gained the Victoria Cross in the Indian Mutiny by many acts of conspicuous daring, and a nephew of General Sir Hugh Henry Gough, who also bears this same high trophy for bravery at the taking of the Alum Bagh and at Lucknow, thas completing the remarkable record of three members of one family possessing the "badgeof valour.' The new aide-de-camp entered the Army in 1892 as a second lieutenant in the Rifle Brigade and first saw active service in the | Soudan campaign of 1898. During the follow-

ing year he went to South Africa and was subsequently present throughout the whole of the recent operations there, taking part in the action at Lombard's Kop and the defence of Ladysmith, &c., which secured him mention in despatches, the brevet of major, and the medal with three clasps. In 1903 he went through the campaign in Somaliland, and was awarded the Victoria Cross for gallantry at Daratoleh, wben he assisted Captains Walker and Rolland in | carrying back Captain Bruce, who was mortally wounded and prevented that officer from falling | into the hands of the enemy. Lieut. Colonel Gough, who was personally decorated with the V.C. by his Majesty at St. James's Palace on Feb. 29, 1904, holds at present a Staff appointment in Ireland.

div.head: THE AGRICULTURAL BANK
div.p: We are anthorised to state that the statei ments being published in the various papers,
wreign and native, as to the intentions of the
Agricultural Bank to buy corn from its clients Duror establish shoonas for taking grain in pledget et are incorrect and that no occasion has arisen
for the Bank to abandon its ordinary procedure.
Reviewing the sound investments of Egypt the "African World" says :

One of the first stocks to benefit by the improved state of affairs will undoubtedly be Agricultural Bank of Egypt. The bank, which is engaged exclusively in the business of making loans to native cultivators, showed for 1906 a net profit of £558,275. Only the interest actually recovered during any financial year can be taken into account; provision is made against overdue loans and interest. Independently of such provision a reserve fund is being : formed by a statutory annual deduction of five per cent. from the interest collected. This deduction or charge amounted to £41,535 for | 1906, bringing the reserve fund to £102,700, which is invested in Egyptian Government securities. This reserve fund becomes ultimately the property, in equal division, of the ordinary, and deferred shareholders, and may be regarded by the investor as insuring the return of the premium he may pay in price over the par value of these shares. The bank was originally established in 1902. Its authorised share capital amounted to £10,310,000, of which £8,810,000 has been issued, leaving a further £1,500,000 of debenture capital to be issued.

Dividends have been paid as under :- | Year. Ordinary Shares. Deferred Shares. li ) 1903 ....... 5 per cent. 1904 ........ 6 per cent. ....... £6 5.0 1905 ....... 71 per cent. ....... £15 15 0 1906 ....... 9 per cent. ....... £49 150
It is estimated that when the whole of the debenture capital is issued and employed, the | profits will admit of a dividend of 10 per cent. ! I on the ordinary shares and 462 58. on the deferred.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: Messrs. Collinge Bros., Liverpool, in their weekly report dated August 16th state that the past week has been a rather active one and closes at a net advance of 16 to 17 points. , The excessive heat and drought is said to have caused considerable damage to the plant,
principally in Texas. Should these conditions | continue, we will no doubt see higher prices
still, bat it must not be forgotten, that a good | deal of the recent advance has been caused by
manipulation and should needed rain fall, the is | market would have a quick setback,

div.head: "TO SEE WITH OTHERS' EYES."
div.p: To the Editor Of The "EGYPTIAN Gazette."

Dear Sir, I have been a regular subscriber to your paper for many years and during the whole time have never read such a miserable, uncalledfor letter as that in your paper of yesterday's | issue signed 'Disgusted."

On Saturday evening my business caused me to be on the scene of the most good natured, h inoffensive, unobstructive, and amusing little incident that any one could witness. All nationalities present were amused for about three minutes and not the slightest harm done to anyone, and certainly no bad reflection can 1 rest on anyone concerned. The police who witnessed it enjoyed the fun and had no reason to interfere. "Disgusted" must be & puerile pessimist and shonld not be allowed out after dark withont a nurse. I have not the personal acquaintance of anyone concerned but think from a point of fairness and as an eye witness it is my duty to write the truth. I enclose my card and remain.
Yours faithfully,

div.head: THE ALHAMBRA THEATRE.
div.p: Delightful music, pleasurable singing, excellent staging-sueh are the features that supported last night's representation of "Les Petites Brebis" at the above theatre. The piece is a gem, fit to rank with "La Poupée," | which is saying a great deal, and quite French in its treatment. A natty little two act gem, giving fine opportunities to the two tenors for the display of their voices, and such duets as we were treated to, are alone worth a visit to this troupe ere it departs from our shores. Signor Urbano gave a masterly display and, really, the versatility of this actor is, astonishing. Youth to age; mirth to sorrow ! he ranks as a very high exponent of his art,

This piece was followed by a burlesque on "Il Trovatore" which in spite of its fun was hardly worth staging. But why is the theatre so little patronized ? The company is good and the theatre the best in Alexandria. One is inclined to think that the artistic element in Alexandria cannot rise above the level of a cinemetrograph !

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO
div.p: La direction nous informe que jeudi soir à 9 h. 3/4 aura lieu dans la grande salle des fêtes une soirée musicale donnée par le jeune violoniste Balilla Cajd accompagné au piano par Mlle Maria Tortella. MM. les abonnés ainsi que les clients de l'Hôtel, auront l'entrée libre.

Samedi soir à l'occasion de la fête de nuit, les artistes du Casino accompagnés par l'orchestre Bracale, prêteront leur gracieux concours. Le programme sera des plas choisis. La direction s'est de même assuré le concours de la Philharmonique Grecque qui exécutera un programme très joli, pendant le | diner. A 11 heures 80 sera tiré le plus joli feu d'artifice de la saison.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE.
div.p: Aujourd'hui à tik 1/2 a.m.). -
Le début de pe matin a été déplorable. Outre la hausse continne du taux d'escompte | et la faiblesse des valears égyptiannes haul

Stock Exchange, il faut ajouter comme dle? ment déprimant de notre place l'inondation I d'ordres de vente provenant du Csire. Un seul exemple suffira dans ce sens : la Capitale offrait à un moment donné la National Bank'à 19.1/2. Vers la fin, toutefois, des efforts analogues à ceux des séances précédentes ont permis aux haussiers de relever un pen le cote ; ce qui n'a pas empê ché d'ailleurs l'ensemble des valenrs de de turer à un niveau sensiblement intérieur celui d'hier. Des affaires clairsemées et peu - | importantes ont eg: lien, mais non, comme | cela ressort de ce qui précède, sens de lourds sacrifices de la part des vendeurs. Ce qui n'a pas peu contribué à la reprise c'est l'en mélioration du Caire, où les vendeurs, voyant | sans donte le résultat de Jeat attitude, ont cessé de casser les cours par des offres tembant dans le vide. Si l'on entend par: là que nous avons assez bien prévu ce qui arrive aujourd'hui, c'est vrai'; mais pessimiste dans le sens de baissier nons ne l'avonsj'amais été. Nous pous contentons d'enregistrer les faits et de signaler les tendances, trop heureux si nous pouvons en même temps prévenir de nouvelles catastrophes en combattant les mouvements incansidérés de pure spéculation.

div.head: LE MARCHE A TERME
div.p: Un nouveau règlement du marché à terme rédigé par M. P. Oziol, vice-président de la corporation des Agents de Change du Caire vient d'être adopté par celle-ci. Il stipule que le marché à terme est remis en vigueur : à partir du, 1er septembre 1907 et que les opérations seront traitées à la Corbeille et porteront sur toutes les valeurs au porteur admises à la cote officielle. ..
Nous détachons de ce règlement la partie relative aux obligations des clients pour les opérations à terme :

Toute opération à terme est soumise à la réglementation des marchés à terme adoptée par la Corporation des Agents de Changerdu Caire le 15 août 1907. Les opérations qui, par la faute de l'agent, n'aumient pas été confirmées pár échange de notes officielles, dament signées par les intéressés, portant le timbre de la Corporation, ne seront pas reconnnes valables par la Corponation. le • elient est tenu de verser à l'agent la mange minimum prévue par la réglementation précitée, savoir : 10% sur les valeurs eotées £ 4 et au-dessus; 15% sur les valeurs cotées au-dessous de £4.

"Le client est tenu de suivre et de surveiller par lui-même les cours des valeurs sur lesquelles il a opéré, car il est absolument responsable, du maintien de la marge precitée. Dans le cas où cette marge anrait subi une diminution de moitié, l'agenit aura le droit de liquider immédiatement et sans aucun avis, pour le compte de son client toute opération en cours. Cette liquidation gera effectuée par les délégués da Comité de la Corporation. Le client est tenu de domer par écrit à son agent, vingt-quatre hedres au moins avant le jour de la liquidation, les ordres relatifs à la liquidation des per rations en coura, savoir : soit" lignider au \'5 mieux, payer par chèque ou delegation por tant acceptation de la banque intervenants dans le cas d'abstention idă chiot Tat aura le droit de liquider immédiatement ! sans aucun avis, pour le compte de son client, toute opération en cours. Cetta 11quidation sers effectuée par les délégués, dessa la Corporation."
Le Comité interviendra entra agonta et nisi. clients toutes les fois que le olient royndira met constituers en due forme e Comité bitre amiable compositeur,

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES BT CRITIQUES
Le Caire Lundi 19 Août Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est renseigné en hangge de 1/8 à 4 5/8 pour cent.

Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais est resté invarié à 81 5/8, l'Unifiée à 100 3/4. La National Bank a été soutenue à 20 1/4, l'Agricole à 8 1/8 et la Delta Light à 9 7/8. La Daïra Sanieh a baissé de 1/4 à 12 1/2. .
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien s baissé de 1 franc à 684, les Lots Turcs également à 164. La Banque d'Athènes s'est maintenue à 112.

loi, bien que nos valeurs aient conservé samedi à Londres une fermeté remarquable, en égard aux mauvaises dispositions dont fait preuve le Stock Exchange, il s'est produit dès Kuverture one aggravation de la réaction Corynebede vendredi dernier. Les affaires ont été plutôt clairsemées, les vendeurs, au contraire de ce qu'on pourrait en déduire n'étant pas très nombreux.

Le tassement enregistré nous paralt même être un peu factice, et la clôture aurait pu être beaucoup plus ferme si un certain nombre de baissiers ne s'étaient ingénie à casser les cours dans un but que l'on devine. Néanmoins, nous croyons à une réapparition prochaine des achats de placement, nombre de valeurs présentant de nouveau des cours très tentants, et la réaction actuelle ne paraissant pas devoir se prolonger outre mesure

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la Na tional Bank est ramenée sans affaires à 20. L'Agricole se tasse à 8. La Cassa di Sconto n'est pas mieux tenue à 40 et les fondateurs Société Générale Egyptienne reculent & 43.

Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire haussent à 201. Les obligations Crédit Foncier fléchis. sent à 300 et les nouvelles à 257. L'Allotment retombe à 2 3/8-7/16 et sa part à 66. Les fondateurs Enterprise and Development se réveillent à 10 3/8. L'Agricole du Nil se ressaisit à 190. Les Entreprises Immobilières et Trávaux souffrent des mauvaises dispositions du marché à 2 1/2, tandis que leur fondateur resta ferme à P.T. 45. Les Ciments d'E gypte sont en reprise & 32.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Baehler, très attaqués clôturent assez soutenus à 5 15/16-6. Les Nangovich reculent à 14 3/8, de même que les fondateurs National Hotels à P.T. 34.

Parmi les petites valenrs, la Delta Land revient à 1 3/4-13/16. Les Estates finissent plus faibles à o 11/16 et leur part à 8 3/4. La New Egyptian subit la tendance générale a 15), ainsi que les Abdy å 0 5/8, les United Lands à 0 3/8 et les Ritz à 0 11/16.
Nous détachons de notre correspondance d'Alexandrie, les passages suivants :

"La légère réaction qui s'est manifestée en fin de semaine, a préoccupé les esprits, peutêtre un peu plus qu'elle ne le méritait. Bien que très naturelle, et si peu considérable que toutes les valenrs conservent encore des cours bien supérieurs à ceux de la quinzaine précédente, elle a désorienté un tantinet les optimistes en leur faisant croire qu'il en pourrait résulter une nouvelle période de stagnation, Les baissiers, qui restent nombreux, en ont reçu pn nouvel encouragement et ne se sont pas fait faute de claironner leur pessimisme
intéressé... s er, l'opinion générale est qu'il n'y a la Oqu'une tendance passagere que nous devons
aux mauvaises nouvelles d'Europe touchant l'élévation du taux de l'escompte, ainsi qu'à des réalisations, qui, quoiqu'on en dise parmi les baissiers, ont été fort nombreuses.

"Il est à présumer qu'une fois la première alarme passée, les achats de placement, si nombreux il y a quelques jours, reprendront et ramèneront la cote plus haut qu'elle n'a été depuis fort longtemps.

"La nouvelle du rétablissement du marché à terme au Caire, a été assez favorablement accueillie ici. On pense que ce sera un excellent stimulant pour certaines valeurs, et que notre place sera obligée de prendre la même décision."

D'après la "Gazette de Francfort" le groupe des banques qui avait consenti de prendre 100,000 obligations 4% du Crédit Foncier Egyptien s'est décidé à prendre des titres 3% une partie ferme et une partie à option à 72%. D'antre part'le placement de Pons 4% auprès du gouvernement khedivial est avantageux pour le Crédit Foncier Egyptien car il peut replacer cet argent à 7% avec la latitude de pouvoir émettre le moment venu de nouvelles obligations,
Les recettes de l'Egyptian Delta Light Rail ways pour la semaine au 10 Août se sont élevées à L.E. 4,677 contre L.E. 4,024 pour la période correspondante en 1906, soit en aug. mentation de L.E. 653.
Les recettes totales depuis le ler Avri! sont de L.É. 87,286 contre L.E., 73,000 pour l'exercice-précédent, soit en plus-value de L.E. 14,276.

row.cell: The Upper Egypt and Delta Navigation

div.p: 2000 Moors attacked the French yesterday log a front of 6 kilometres. The attack, was releed The Spahis and Turcos serving with the Drench showed extraordinary bravery. General Drnde personally led the troops. One Captain was wounded and two men killed. (H.).
The Moors attacked Casablanca yesterday morning. The French detachment assumed the offensive under cover of shell fire from the warships

(Later): The Kabyles lacked ammunition but .charged home with swords. Two of the French have been killed and three/wounded. The tribesmen probably sufered heavy loss. The Spaniards did not participate. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE HAGUE CONFERENCE.
FRY'S RESOLUTION ADOPTED.

div.p: The Conference adopted Sir Edward Fry's -resolution by acclamation but it was generally felt that the approbation was purely platonic. Sir Edward Fry likewise made a declaration against the use of the dum-dum bullet and explosives, with asphyxiating gases. (Reuter)

div.head:
SITUATION IN PERSIA.
APPEAL TO THE SHAR.

div.p: The executive is inactive, criminals go unpunished, and lawlessness is increasing. The President and 6 members of Parliament have presented an address regarding the state of affairs to the Shah who has promised his utmost assistance, even to the dismisal. of hostile members of his entonrage. (Reuter)

div.head:
FIRE AT ŞEA.
.. CREW AND PASSENGERS SAFE.

div.p: The sbip "Forth" has arrived here with the crew and passengers of the steamer Fortunatus," bound from Calcutta to Melbourne, which was burned at sen on 31st July. The boats were picked up 600 miles sonth of Sumatra. One stoker lost his life. (Reuter)
King Edward has invited M. Clémencean to dinner on Wednesday.
( arvus)
Cholera has broken ont in Russian Poland.
(Reuter)
The general council have opened. They paid homage to the bravery of the soldiers who are fighting at Morocco.
(Harys.)
Cricket. Third Test Match. Englishmen 112 runs for 3 wickets. Rain, interrupted. England same as on 29th July except that Crawford | replaced Arnoid. At the close, England 226 runs for 7 wickets.

div.head: THE NEW MEDITERRANEAN COMMAND.
div.p: The military correspondent of the "Times," in a long and interesting article on the above, says:

The appointment of his Royal Highness the Duke ofConnaught as Field-MarshalCommanding-in-Chief the Mediterránean. Forces and High Commissioner in the Mediterranean must have been anticipated by every one who read Mr. Haldane's Memorandum. on the Army Estimates for 1907-8.

The approaching departure of the Duke from the United Kingdom is on several counts very much to be regretted. On the Selection Board his Royal Highness's well-known impartiality and fairness have contributed largely to the prestige of that important body and have offered a security that the interests of all concerned would be fully considered, even if they could not all be satisfied, in the filling of the higher appointments in the Army. As Inspector General; the Bake has been able to keep in touch with the officers and men of the Army at home and in the Colonies, and thus to maintain his unequalled acquaintence with the personnel of his Majesty's forces. No one can quite replace, though he may succeed, the Dake in this particular sphere of activity.
It has been the consistent policy of the Crown, 1 and of the best advisers of the Crown, to main

tain its touch with the Army by ciose personal intercourse, whether excercised by the Sovereign or by some member of the Royal House. The presence of the Duke of Cambridge at every military ceremonial of importance in the United Kingdom during the lifetime of most British soldiers now living was the outward and visible sign of the dependence of the Army upon the Crown. The presence of the Duke of Connaught, į as Inspector General, at all great military manæuyres, parades, and inspections continued this personal intercourse, which has ever proyed a source of strength to both. The high regard for the public interest and the inde. fatigable energy of the Duke of Connaught have set an elevated standard of duty to the Army, while his presence with the troops hás added a lustre to their ceremonial and man euvres, and has proved of great and indisputable advantage to the Army at large. The future restriction of the Duke's sphere of activity to the comparatively unimportant area of our Mediterranean garrisons withdraws his Royal Highness from contact with the great body of the Army and deprives it of a source of strength and of a canse of contentment.

Nor can one truly say, from a purely military point of view and placing aside for the moment all personal and ulterior considerations, that ther presende of a military commander-in-chief in the Mediterranean is either desiderable or useful. We occupied a larger number of garrisons in the Mediterreanean in the year 1915, at the moment when the hundred days began, than we do now. We held Malta and Gibraltar then as now; we had troops in Sicily acting in support of his Sicilian Majesty, we had garrisons in the 'Seven Islands, and attached great importance to Corfu ; finally, we had a force at Genoa. Yet the British Government of the day considered it fitting to withdraw their commander-in-chief, LieutenantGeneral Lord William Bentinck; to ask him to consider the Mediterranean Army as broken mp; and to direct him and the officers of his general staff that they were at liberty to return to England. The reasons given for this step appear to be applicable to the existing situation. "The British troops in the Mediterranean," wrote Lord Bathurst when communicating the decision of the Govern ment, to Lord William Bentinck, "are at present unequal to do more than garrison certain fortresses, which are so distant from each other, and so unconnected in their interests and systems of defence, that it would be rather embarrassing than convenient to consider the troops stationed in these dif ferent places as forming one whole, or united upder one commander."

What, exa:tly, is the Duke's responsibility in the new appointment ? It is rather more easy to explain wliat he is not to do. The Colonial Office does not admit his interposition as intermediary between Lord Elgin and the Governors of Malta and Gibraltar. These Governors are to remain solely responsible for all matters of administration subject to the existing control from home. In Egypt and the Sudan all civil and political matters are to be dealt with as heretofore by the Agent and Consul-General in Egypt. Both Foreign and Colonial Offices thus retain all their powers intact, and the Duke's appointment as High Commissioner carries nothing with it but the barren honour of the right of precedence at State and other functions. Thus, from the civil side of administration, there is nothing which appears to call for the presence of his Royal Highness in the Mediterranean. | Similarly, in military affairs, all matters of local military administration will be disposed of as bitherto by the Governors of Malta and Gibraltar and by the general officer commanding in Egypt, while the Sirdar will continue to be responsible for the administration of the Sudan and for the Egyptian and Sudanese forces. There are reserved for the Duke's con: trol the more important cases of discipline, not yet defined ; the inspection and training of all | British troops in the Mediterranean, already 1 adequately provided for ; and the considera
tion of questions of strategy which are the proper province of the Defence Committee. He
is further to be consulted on questions of policy c, which involve' military considerations before

the local representatives of the Foreign and Colonial Offices lay their views on such questions before their respective Departments. His Royal Highness will reside at the Palace, Valetta, and will have a yacht at his disposal for carrying out his mission in the Middle Sea. 1: If, therefore, the Duke is at Gibraltar and has to be consulted on important cases of discipline or questions of defence by the authorities in Egypt or the Sudan, some two or three weeks must elapse before his views can be ascertained except by telegraph, and the same thing applies to the westeru garrisons if his Royal Highness is at Cairo or Khartum. If it is not necessary to consult him his presence is not required, and if it is necessary the
delay may be prejudicial. This situation, only - an inconvenience in peace, may become a
danger in time of actual or impending war. We most recognize that there is no real bond of
union between garrisons which are strietly 1 limited to the requirements of their own de--fence except in Egypt and the Sudan, where
they are still below the standard of safety. - It should be made quite clear whether the 1. Duke is or is not responsible for the size and
strength of the garrisons maintained within - his command, or whether the Home Govern-ment divests itself of none of its respon
sibility in this matter. If we assume that the Government maintains all its rights and duties and acts with the advice of the Defence Committee, then no blame can
hereafter attach to his Royal Highness should cour garrisons in the Mediterranean piove too

weak, or should trouble oceur in the Nile delta or an "émeute" in the Sudan. We maintain our position in Egypt, and particularly in the Sudan, by prestige rather than by visible material strength so far as white troops are concerned'; and it is important that we should be told, once and for all, who takes the re

sponsibility for the present situation which . cannot be defended on military grounds. It is In cessary that we should strengthen still more the army of occupation in Egypt; that we shónld increase our cavalry to the strength of | a brigade and mount them on Syrian Arabs;

that we should create a British camel corps for service on the desert frontiers ; and, finally, that the white garrison at Khartum should be reinforced. Without the power of despatching mobile columns throughout the Delta with the utmost promptitude while retaining strong garrisons in Cairo and Alexandria we cannot ensure the internal security of Egypt in all emergencies

It is said that the creation of this new command will involve no increase of expenditure. This is true, but it does involve the abolition of two generals' commands at Malta and Gibraltar and the appointment of lientenantgenerals to posts which have hitherto been highly prized by older officers of the senior grade. Certain other changes have also been made to balance accounts on the side of finance. This is not an advantageous measure. There are very few desirable appointments left for senior officers who have deserved well of their country, and in proportion as we reduce such | appointments the popularity of the Army decreases and with it the number of applications for first commissions. The economy is only on the surface, since it leads inevitably in time to the increase of the pay of the lower ranks in the corps of officers; and a very slight addition to the pay of subaltern officers more than swallows up the saving caused by the reduc-11 tion of appointments. The worst thing ever | done in this matter was the abolition of the £1,000 a year which went with the command of regiments bestowed upon officers who had served their country well. It was a comparatively poor England which thus rewarded men who had risked their lives and often sacrificed their health in her defence, and it is an England bursting with riches that sterilizes the recruiting of the commissioned ranks by steadily restricting the prizes afforded by the career of arms.

There is thus much which appears to cause the new command to be regarded as one of doubtful wisdom, and we have to seek the real motive and excuse for the creation of the new appointment in other considerations. The Duke of Connaught was appointed Inspector-General of the Forces on May 1, 1904, and his duties were regulated by an Order in Council a few days later. In a higher military sense the appointment has not given the results expected. His Royal Highness has not been invariably well treated. He has not been kept sufficiently in touch with proceedings of the War Office. His reports, reputed to be of much value, have not seen the light and the public has no knowledge whether the recommendations which have followed his inspections have or have not been carried out. There has been little or no visible influence npon the organization and administration of the Army arising from his inspections and reports. One Minister, no longer in office, went so far as to suggest that the Duke should alter one of his reports. The presence of the Inspector-General,

div.head: DEATH OF A FAMOUS DENTIST.
div.p: The Berlin Correspondent of "The Times" | announces the death of Dr. W. D. Miller, till last year Professor of Odontology in the University of Berlin. Professor Miller was known throughout the world in the circles of his profession as, perhaps, the first scientific author ity on the teeth. An American by birth, he had practised and taught in Berlin for upwards of 30 years, and, besides enriching the literature of his subject with a large number of scientific treatises, he had been for a long time at the head of the Berlin University Dental Institute. Many of his experimental discoveries were epoch-making, and his anthority was undisputed on the physiology and pathol- ! ogy of the teeth. His historical knowledge of his subject was also extraordinarily wide in range and curious in detail. He once delivered a singularly interesting lecture on "The Dentistry of the Ancient Egyptians," the result of special studies of Egyptian remains. His many friends in Berlin, where he was a popular member of the American colony and of the German scientific world, and where he founded the Berlin Golf Club and introduced the game of golf, in which he excelled, will learn with regret that his death should have so closely followed upon his appointment to a chair of odontology at Michigan University, where he had hoped to spend the evening of his days in the country of his birth and of his unwavering affection.
